Stocks put in a second straight day of gains Wednesday, as the Fed left interest rates unchanged but possibly moved closer to hiking them.
The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.7% each, while the Nasdaq rose 0.4%. Volume was lower across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.
The Fed, as expected, made no change on interest rates. But it upgraded its view of the labor market, which could be viewed as a hawkish stance.

Inphi (IPHI) jumped 5% after bouncing back from earlier weakness. Late Tuesday, the data networking technology firm beat views with Q2 earnings that surged 167% to 24 cents a share. That marked its seventh straight quarter of triple-digit growth. Sales grew 79% to $60.7 million, also above views. But CEO Ford Tamer was cautious on China. The reversal put Inphi back above a 21.43 buy point from a consolidation cleared in late April.

Earnings jumped 35% to 77 cents a share, the third straight period of growth acceleration. Sales grew 17% to $497.6 million, the biggest increase in two years. The stock cleared a 78.19 buy point from a flat base.
Icon (ICLR) added 3%, following through from Tuesday's breakout past a 72.50 buy point from a flat base. The Irish provider of clinical research services reported mixed quarterly results Tuesday.

On the downside, Tableau Software (DATA) ended off its session low, but still tumbled 11% in hefty turnover. Stock futures were moderately lower, but off earlier lows on the ramp-up to Tuesday's open. Dow futures had nearly halved their hour-earlier loses, trading 29.4 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures narrowed their decline to 20.7 points. S&P 500 futures were 7.5 points underwater.

Global markets had little premarket impact on the stock market today. Europe's leading indexes recovered early losses to trade in tightly mixed action near midday. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 1%. Hong Kong eased a fraction. China's mainland markets remain closed on holiday.

Economic news gave markets little to go on. A slump in Germany's August manufacturing orders had an early effect on eurozone markets. The U.S. trade deficit widened to $48.3 billion in August from $41.9 billion in July, but less than the $48.6 billion projected by economists.
Kansas City Federal Reserve Bank President Esther George is scheduled to speak at 9:30 a.m. ET. John Williams, president of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, speaks at 3:30 p.m.
Company news was central to early stock action. PepsiCo (PEP) set the third-quarter earnings season in motion, jumping 3% after a healthy revenue and earnings beat.

Chip developer PMC-Sierra (PMCS) bucked up 31%. Woburn, Mass.-based Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) said it would buy the Sunnyvale, Calif., company in an all-cash deal valued at $ 2 billion. Skyworks said it expects the combined companies to generate more than $4 billion in revenue, with 55% gross margins and operating margins above 40%. Skyworks shares rose a bit less than 1%.

DuPont (DD) jetted ahead more than 6% after a torrent of late news Monday. The company lowered its full-year operating earnings guidance to $2.75 per share from $3.10. The company cited continuing strength of the U.S. dollar and weak currency and agricultural markets in Brazil.

DuPont also announced that CEO Ellen Kullman will retire effective Oct. 16. Board member Edward Breen will assume Kullman's duties on an interim basis. The company has been under pressure from hedge fund Trian Fund Management to cut costs and divest assets. DuPont shares ended Monday 36% below their March high.

The drugmaker du jour is U.K.-based Novocure (NVCR), which nabbed a 10% advance on news that the Food and Drug Administration approved its Optune, a tumor-treatment device for use in patients suffering from glioblastoma — fast-growing brain tumors.

Illumina (ILMN) dimmed 16% in premarket action. The gene-sequencing leader pre-reported Q3 revenue below consensus expectations and guided its full-year revenue growth to 18% vs. consensus views of 21%. Illumina shares had been in a steepening decline since July.

Among leaders, D.R. Horton (DHI) slipped more than 3% ahead of the open. The homebuilder surged 5% in weak trade Monday, retaking its 50-day moving average. The stock ended Monday almost 8% above a 28.80 buy point.

Square (SQ), Mastercard (MA), Visa (V), PayPal (PYPL) and Verisk Analytics (VRSK) held up nicely Tuesday even as financial stocks overall tumbled from Italy's political woes. Square, which tried to break out amid the selling Tuesday, moved back above the buy zone Wednesday, while Mastercard and Visa remain above entry points.Shares of Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank of America (BAC) tumbled between 4% and 6% Tuesday each as investors sought safety in U.S. Treasurys, pushing the rate on the benchmark 10-year note down to 2.79%. The two-year yield skidded, but not as much, to 2.34%, squeezing the yield spread and banks' profitability on loans. (These Wall Street giants rose modestly Wednesday, with Treasury yields recouping some losses.)But financial stocks with less exposure to falling interest rates were relatively unscathed. Visa and Mastercard, for example, oversee vast payment networks but don't issue credit cards directly, unlike fellow Dow Jones components JPMorgan and American Express (AXP). That means they aren't exposed to lower rates or credit risk directly. Payments firms PayPal and Square also are largely insulated from interest rates, though Square does make some loans to small businesses. Verisk provides underwriting data analytics to the insurance industry.Here's how these five financial stocks, each of which is in a buy zone or near a buy point, are performing. The poor stock market performance in March and the first quarter took its toll on many of the best mutual funds, according to IBD's latest Best Mutual Funds Performance Report. But mutual fund managers who spoke with IBD are not hitting the panic button yet. In fact, they point to a silver lining."The pullback has taken some of the richness out of stock valuations," said Vladimir "Val" de Vassal, co-manager of $2.8 billion Glenmede Large Cap Core Fund (GTLOX), a 2018 IBD Best Mutual Funds Award winner. Each of those top mutual funds beat its benchmark in 2017 and over the past three, five and 10 years as of Dec. 31. Only 10.4% of eligible U.S. diversified stock funds made the Best Mutual Funds Awards list. "A drop in valuations is good," he added.Meanwhile, how weak was stock market performance? March's 2.54% setback marked the S&P 500's second straight monthly decline after 15 straight monthly gains. The bogey's 0.76% Q1 reversal was its first after nine straight quarterly advances. Likewise, the 0.93% March decline by the average U.S. diversified stock mutual fund was its second in a row after five monthly climbs. The group's 0.38% Q1 shrinkage was its first after seven quarterly gains in a row.Investors were jolted in part by fears of inflation, de Vassal said. That arose from January's strong payroll numbers — 200,000 jobs created instead of the 180,000 that were expected — and 2.9% rise in average hourly wages versus the prior year. Later downward revisions eased investors' concerns, but those jitters were replaced by new ones stemming from concerns about a possible trade war, sparked by U.S. tariffs on Chinese aluminum and steel, and the falloff by technology stocks.Still, many mutual fund managers look beyond the weak March and Q1 stock market performance and see encouraging signs. "The economy looks good," said Chip Reed, co-manager of $11.6 billion Eaton Vance Atlanta Capital SMID-Cap Fund (EISMX), another 2018 IBD Best Mutual Funds Award winner. "The market looks good. We have the tax stimulus package. We have global synchronized recovery in economic growth for the first time since the 1990s. It doesn't get better than this."Despite U.S. diversified stock mutual funds' March fall, small-cap growth funds managed a 1.23% gain. That made them the best-performing subgroup. They also led Q1 overall by advancing 3.13%.And in contrast to the losses on average by U.S. diversified stock mutual funds in March and Q1, world equity funds eked out a 0.11% Q1 gain despite slipping 0.85% in March. Pacific ex Japan funds led world regions in March by posting the smallest setback, 0.35%. Latin American funds led foreign stock fund categories in Q1 with a 5.57% advance.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseBut the weakest market moved sharply in the opposite direction. India region funds plunged 7.51% in Q1, trimming their five-year average annual gain to 11.90%, still best among foreign stock markets.Among major sectors, real estate funds topped the pack in March with a 3.36% gain. Global science/technology funds' 5.53% advance was tops in Q1.Precious metals funds did worst among sectors in Q1, plummeting 7.21%, despite gaining 1.93% in March amid jitters about inflation and a possible trade war.On average, taxable bond funds gained in March but lost ground in Q1. Tax-exempt bond funds as a group also rose in March but sank in Q1.Despite the macro factors fueling his constructive outlook, Eaton Vance's Reed added that a trade war and high valuations could disrupt the party. "You need to be cautious," he said.Matthew Moberg, lead manager of $5 billion Franklin DynaTech (FKDNX), a third 2018 IBD Best Mutual Funds Award winner, says investors should expect continued volatility for the rest of this year. Otherwise, he is constructive. "A combination of tax reform and earnings increases is good," he said. "And inflation is being held in check by large internet platforms."Further, despite the recent tech stock sell-off, Moberg's tech-focused fund remains bullish on select tech names. "The fund invests in innovation," Moberg said. "Places where we are invested still have a lot of secular growth."In cloud computing, Moberg likes the huge lead that Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT) have in a growing market. In mobile advertising, he says Alphabet (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB) are growing and enjoying solid profitability.Three companies dominate chipmaking. He owns Intel (INTC) but not Samsung or Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM). In the payments arena, he cites secular growth by Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA).In the software space, he likes ServiceNow (NOW). "This company helps information-technology departments," Moberg said. "Their software is finding new applications."Reed looks for all-weather stocks. "We look for holdings that can do well in any environment," he said. "Our holdings tend to be companies that are somewhat immune to the economic cycle."One is Verisk Analytics (VRSK). "They sell data on insurance claims (mainly to property and casualty) insurance companies that they receive from other insurers," Reed said. "They have a reservoir of information and tax records." The company also has an insurance unit focused on risk assessment, rating and risk modeling for the oil and gas, petrochemicals, power-generation, and metals and mining industries.Markel (MKL) is another Reed favorite. "They're a specialty insurance company," he said. "They don't compete with big insurers. They underwrite insurance for bars, day care centers. The risks are higher, but that enables them to demand higher premiums."Reed also holds Blackbaud (BLKB), a cloud software company focused on nonprofits. "They design software that helps nonprofits run their business, from the accounting side to the fundraising side."Blackbaud's programs enable nonprofits to focus on core missions rather than allocate resources to developing their own software, Reed said. "They are dominant in that industry, and they expanding into education," he said.YOU MAY ALSO LIKE:You Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And IncomeIn A Volatile Market: Go To Cash Or Stay The Course With Your Mutual Funds?

TransUnion (TRU) may not be the hottest name in the market or have the same brand recognition as, say, Apple (AAPL), but its stock has been on fire of late.A growing consumer credit market is benefiting the provider of consumer reports, risk scores and analytics, and TransUnion's diversification is helping it stand out from the pack. The company has transformed beyond its consumer credit roots and into a diversified risk management analytics firm. That's translated to soaring organic revenue growth and significant share price gains.Helping the Chicago-based company is what JPMorgan says is its extension into data sets that had been underutilized by consumer credit reporting vendors. That includes public records data such as court judgments, bankruptcies, liens, marriages and divorces. There's also driver history data as well as alternative data, including information on consumers with thin credit files."While modest in scope currently, these unique offerings are growing quickly and morph TransUnion from a traditional (consumer reporting agency) into a diversified risk management solutions firm with an expanded addressable market," JPMorgan analyst Andrew Steinerman said in an April 27 note to clients.He added that this evolution helps distinguish the June 2015 initial public offering from its primary competitors, namely Experian and Equifax (EFX), which is a member of Investor's Business Daily's IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks. The analyst notes that TransUnion is increasing its comparability to companies such as privately held LexisNexis Risk Solutions and Verisk Analytics (VRSK) as well.A Zacks Equity Research report on May 10 noted the company’s financial appeal, saying it has highly recurring and diversified revenue streams, significant operating leverage, low capital requirements and cash flows that are "strong and stable.""Impressively, it deals with the 10 largest U.S. banks, the top 5 credit card issuers, the biggest 25 auto lenders, thousands of healthcare providers and federal, state and local government agencies," the Zacks report added.That recipe of a strong business model and notable client exposure had a positive impact on the company’s latest quarterly results. After the market close on April 26, TransUnion reported a 60% rise in first-quarter adjusted earnings to 32 cents a share, beating analyst estimates for 26 cents. Revenue climbed 15% to $406 million for the quarter, handily topping projections for $380 million."In our view, a beat in (2016's first quarter) was perhaps foreseeable, but the extent to which (TransUnion's) results outperformed despite lapping tougher (year-over-year) comps was exemplary," JPMorgan's Steinerman said.TransUnion’s U.S. information services segment saw revenue grow 13% to $247 million, accounting for 57% of the top line total. Revenue from the company’s international business increased 7% to 68 million, with 5% of the growth due to acquisitions. The company said the international segment’s revenue growth would have been 22% on a constant currency basis.Consumer interactive revenue jumped 25% to $105 million, driven by strength in both direct and indirect solutions."The new growth initiative investments, and productivity investments at Spark (a company analytics and technology investment project) are together helping to fuel not only impressive top line growth, but also notable margin expansion," said TransUnion Chief Executive Jim Peck during the company's quarterly conference call on April 26.TransUnion raised its full-year guidance, but it was on the conservative side. The company sees 2016 EPS in the range of $1.30 to $1.34, up from $1.24 to $1.28 previously. The midpoint of $1.32 was a hair below projections for $1.33.TransUnion upped its revenue expectation to $1.63 billion to $1.65 billion, from $1.6 billion to $1.62 billion, while analysts have modeled $1.66 billion."While representing a slowdown from 2015’s remarkable growth rates, 2016 guidance is likely lower due to mortgage assumptions, tough year-over-year comps, and beginning-of-year conservatism," Steinerman said. "We find these goals achievable and we note guidance’s implication that (TransUnion's) breadth and pace of growth will remain best-in-class."Wall Street seems to have agreed. Shares vaulted 8.5% the day after the report to become extended from the 5% buy range from a cup-with-handle base it initially broke out of on March 29. Shares are now extended roughly 14% from the 27.15 buy point, after hitting a new all-time high and nearing the 20% profit-taking zone on May 10.TransUnion has risen roughly 38% from its June 2015 IPO price of 22.50. The stock earns an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of 99, meaning it outperforms 98% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Those factors include earnings and sales growth, profit margins, return on equity and relative share price performance.Looking ahead, TransUnion has more growth opportunities -- though it has strong prior-year metrics to compete against."While we acknowledge tougher comps in the back half of the year, we are comfortable with (TransUnion's) forecasted margin expansion and continued strength in emerging verticals such as healthcare and insurance, in addition to the (2016's second half) launch of trended data with Fannie Mae that should boost performance," Cowen and Company analyst George Mihalos said in an April 27 research report.Steinerman says the company's management team is a "critical component" to the company's success."Under current broad leadership, the company has diversified into tangential data sets/data analytics and has overhauled its technology infrastructure," he said.

Stocks rolled out thin gains that quickly turned to mixed action, then losses in early trade Thursday. The Nasdaq slumped 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. The S&P 500 sits a fraction in the red, buoyed by energy issues.
Volume was mixed, up 10% on the NYSE and 6% lower on the Nasdaq, vs. trade at the same time Wednesday.

Verisk Analytics has watched its stock price soar to new highs, again and again, after its quarterly earnings reports. The stock notched a new high a couple of weeks ago after the company reported second-quarter earnings. The same thing occurred after it posted first-quarter and 2014 fourth-quarter results.Verisk (VRSK) provides risk assessment services and decision analytics to professionals in a variety of fields, including property/casualty insurance, financial services, health care, government, human resources and energy — the last of which it entered in May via the biggest acquisition in its history.The company has been on a pretty good roll of late, with three straight quarters of accelerated earnings gains.Earnings AccelerateAfter the close on July 28, Verisk posted a 35% year-over-year earnings increase — its biggest in at least a dozen quarters. Results easily surpassed consensus analyst views. The next day Verisk stock climbed 9% to a record high of 79.88 intraday before closing up 7% to 78.60.Similar spikes occurred on April 29, a day after Verisk reported Q1 results, and on Feb. 25, the day after it reported 2014 fourth-quarter earnings.How does Verisk view such stock action?"It's always interesting to try to understand that. Fundamentally, I'd say all of our verticals are doing well," said Eva Huston, Verisk's senior vice president and chief knowledge officer.In addition, she told IBD, the company has "a lot of consistency" in terms of financial performance."Investors value that," she said.That consistency is partly the result of having expertise that spans more than 40 years.Verisk was founded in 1971 when Insurance Services Office, or ISO, launched operations as a not-for-profit advisory and rating organization providing services for the U.S. property/casualty insurance industry. The original business remains part of the company's Risk Assessment segment. Verisk also operates a Decision Analytics segment, which now makes up the bulk of the business.The Risk Assessment segment primarily helps property/casualty customers define, measure and manage risk via the flagship ISO subsidiary as well as several other units. The products and tools include data and statistical services, actuarial services, standardized insurance policy programs, underwriting information and rating-integrity tools.Its Decision Analytics segment provides a wide variety of customers with tools to help them make informed decisions about managing their assets and risk. These tools are used to predict future losses, select and price risk, detect and prevent fraud and quantify losses that have already happened.Decision Analytics Drive GrowthIn the second quarter, the Decision Analytics business posted a 24.6% revenue increase to $325.9 million, with more than half of the gain coming from the insurance sector. Revenue in the Risk Assessment segment grew 6% to $171.7 million.Total revenue for Verisk rose 17.5% to $497.6 million. Organic revenue, which excluded recent acquisitions and other items, grew 9.4% year over year.Verisk's second-quarter earnings came in at 77 cents a share, up 35.1% from a year earlier and well above consensus estimates for 66 cents.Technology Pays BackMuch of Verisk's recent profit growth can be traced to what it calls a "build it once, sell it many times" revenue model, as well as investments the company has made in new solutions, Huston says."Over the past few years we have been doing more investing in our business, thinking up new analytics to help customers run their businesses better," she said.Huston cites the company's investments into its new software platform called Touchstone. Touchstone is designed to perform advanced analytics to help companies better assess their risk."That took a fair amount of investment, but it allows us to increase our revenue growth," Huston said. "We are now providing a solution that might have been used in a small portion of the insurance industry before, but can now be used by underwriters and a wider portion of the industry."Similar investments have been made in Verisk's aerial imagery tools. Among other things, these tools let insurance customers view structures from their computers to assess associated risk. This lets them avoid the time and cost of visiting the structures themselves.Verisk's biggest investment came in May, when it closed its $2.8 billion acquisition of Wood Mackenzie, a Scotland-based provider of data analytics and commercial intelligence for the energy, chemicals, metal and mining industries.One major benefit of the acquisition — the biggest in Verisk's history — is that it greatly expands the company's global footprint."Wood Mackenzie has offices around the world — in Tokyo, Hong Kong, China, Australia, all throughout Europe," Huston said. "We can leverage that footprint into selling our existing solutions into those markets. For example, we have the opportunity to expand our footprint into China, where we didn't have a presence."In a recent report, JPMorgan analyst Andrew Steinerman noted that "WoodMac has the ability to transform Verisk on the global front," though the acquisition "bears risk due to its energy end market." He also expects reinvestments in WoodMac "to boost revenues over the medium term."The deal has already paid bottom-line benefits, notes Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst Arash Soleimani: "Verisk's (Q2) outperformance relative to our estimate stemmed mostly from likely recurring tax benefits associated with WoodMac's UK domicile and higher-than-expected gross margins."Apple And Android AppsMeanwhile, Verisk continues to broaden its product lineup. On Aug. 5, it announced that its Verisk Insurance Solutions unit launched the ISO ClaimSearch mobile application available on Apple's (AAPL) iTunes and Google 's (GOOG) Google Play.The app gives subscribers, including adjusters and investigators, a new tool that provides real-time access to the company's database of claims."ISO ClaimSearch mobile users will see instant search results to help them investigate and adjust claims more efficiently, whether they're on a roof, in a salvage yard, in a home, at a business, or at a catastrophe site," Carlos Martins, vice president and general manager of ISO ClaimSearch Solutions, said in a statement.Users will be able to securely access the claims inquiry function on ISO ClaimSearch via their iPhone, iPad or Android phone and tablet.Verisk has an IBD Composite Rating of 95. The company belongs to IBD's Commercial Services-Market Research group, which ranks No. 64 of 197 industries tracked. The group's biggest stocks by market cap are Thomson Reuters (TRI) and Moody's (MCO).

Investors should be on the lookout for large-cap companies that offer all the perks of big companies like liquidity and institutional support but still be nimble enough to deliver strong profit growth and stock gains.
Here are the top five stocks on IBD's Big Cap Screen of the Day, which features large stocks with strong earnings and price performance:

BlackRock (BLK), the world's largest money manager, leads the group. BlackRock shares have risen 21.5% on the year, rising 2.6% in the stock market today. Earlier this month the company announced it would trim 3% of its workforce while expanding its three-year partnership with Fidelity Investments. Fidelity customers will be able to trade 65 BlackRock iShares ETFs without paying commission, up from the 30 funds previously available.
BlackRock is ranked No. 29 on the IBD 50, which lists of companies based on superior earnings, strong price performance and leadership within industries.

Verisk Analytics (VRSK) provides risk-actuarial data for insurers. Shares have risen 16% since Jan. 1. Shares shot up nearly 8% on Feb. 27 after the company reported better-than-expected profit and accelerating revenue growth. Verisk has posted 14 straight quarters of double-digit earnings growth. Shares closed at a new high of 61.38 on Tuesday.

LinkedIn (LNKD) is a social networking site for professionals. Users can upload resumes, search for jobs and message with prospective employers or employees. Unlike its larger rival Facebook (FB), LinkedIn has hit the sweet spot for targeting ads and getting users to pay for premium content. Facebook rose 8 cents to 25.21 on Tuesday after hitting a 2013 low Monday.

The biotech Celgene (CELG) announced Tuesday it received orphan status for a drug it's developing with Acceleron Pharma to treat two rare blood diseases. Celgene hit another bump earlier this month after reporting disappointing phase-three results for apremilast, its experimental oral treatment for psoriasis. Still shares closed at a new high of 114.28 on March 14. Celgene is ranked No. 4 on the IBD 50.

Irish Budget airliner Ryanair (RYAAY) rounds out the top five. Last week the company announced a $15.6 billion order for 175 passenger jets from Boeing (BA). The deal is expected to boost Ryanair's fleet from 300 planes to 400 and help boost passenger capacity 25% to 100 million passengers per year by 2018.
Ryanair shares have risen nearly 23% to 42.50, closing at a new high of 43.23 on March 20.

There's an old saying about something being as bad as "a poke in the eye with a sharp stick."On a stock chart, the Nasdaq's dive from a short-term high July 22 to an intraday low Aug. 9 felt like a poke in the eye with a sharp stick 1.In just 12 sessions, the Nasdaq lopped off 527 points, or 18%.Insult was added to injury a few months later when the Nasdaq marked a lower intraday low Oct. 4 2. But that move wasn't straight down. It was more like "a slap across the face with a wet fish," which offers its own form of investing discomfort.Forced to choose between the two pains, most investors would rather suffer a slap across the face with a wet fish than a poke in the eye with a sharp stick. Yet whatever damage was suffered from July to October, disciplined investors were asking this question: What stocks outperformed during this back-to-back turmoil?The outperformers were, and in some cases still are, worth a look. A stock that outperforms the market during a negative swing is showing strength. Sometimes, though not always, that strength will persist, providing future opportunities.Let's go back and look at the period from late July to early October. What stocks did well?Some stocks — such as credit card provider MasterCard (MA), drug developer Celgene (CELG) and risk assessment services provider Verisk Analytics (VRSK) — showed strength by finishing that period only 1% down vs. the Nasdaq's 18% drop.Now, no investor is in the game to lose less than the averages. Getting poor slowly is no virtue. But a stock that keeps its loss small during a big decline is showing extraordinary strength. Such stocks probably belong on a watch list.Other stocks actually notched gains during the decline from July 22 through Oct. 3. They include:• Discount retailer Dollar General (DG), which rose 11%. The stock shaped a cup-with-handle base and broke out past a 34.27 buy point Aug. 30.• Randgold Resources (GOLD), up 9%. The stock broke out in mid-July and advanced while the market corrected.• Newmont Mining (NEM), up 8%. The stock cleared a resistance area in a consolidation in late August.• Dollar Tree (DLTR), up 7%. The stock broke out of a seven-week base in late August.• AutoZone (AZO), up 5%. The stock cleared a pattern in late August.• O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), up 4%. The stock cleared a V-shaped pattern in early September.• Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), up 3%. The stock cleared a six-week consolidation in September.• Advance Auto Parts (AAP), up 1%. This stock made the list on a technicality. While it rose 1% during the July-October turbulence, it began sliding sharply in May.

To lead people effectively, Scott Stephenson starts by asking himself a simple question: How do I want to be treated?

"It's Golden Rule thinking," said Stephenson, president and chief operating officer of Verisk Analytics (VRSK), a Jersey City, N.J.-based firm that offers risk assessment services. "When I've been most productive, I've had bosses who model this kind of leadership."

Stephenson, 54, has learned that an organization's energy level never exceeds the energy level of its top leaders. So he not only tries to treat everyone the way he'd want to be treated but also engages others with enthusiasm and bats around ideas with them.
A Tight-Loose Fit
Many executives adopt what Stephenson calls a "loose-tight mode" to manage people.
That means they loosen their grip when supervising a staffer's job, leaving the worker alone most of the time.

But when a challenge arises or a pivotal decision needs to be made, these executives will swoop in and wrestle authority away from the employee. Suddenly, their management style shifts from loose to tight.
Stephenson, by contrast, prefers a "tight-loose mode."

He engages heavily with direct reports on a regular basis, sharing ideas and asking lots of questions to learn from them. But when the time comes for a critical decision, he backs off and lets them make the final call.
Keep The Calls Coming

Stephenson likes to convey two messages to the heads of Verisk business units. He tells them that they don't have to call him to discuss their performance or issues they face, because he schedules meetings throughout the year for this purpose.
Then he adds, "But you can't call me too often." He explains that he's eager to support their business and serve as a "discussion partner" whenever they'd like to hash out a thorny issue.

He gauges his success in applying the tight-loose approach by the frequent calls he gets from his senior leadership team. He welcomes their conversations about, say, personnel or budget dilemmas that they face.

"When they come to me for my assessment of an issue or my leanings, I discuss the topic and then pause," he said. "It can be a surprising moment to them when I stop and ask, 'What are you going to do?' They're waiting for me to get tight, but I look to them to grapple with it and make a decision."

While Stephenson will intervene on rare occasions when he senses a manager is about to make a disastrous move, he'll usually keep quiet. He encourages people to challenge conventional wisdom, take prudent risks and make their own judgments. If they blunder, he doesn't punish them; instead, he'll ask, "What does that tell us about what we should do in the future?"To lead people effectively, Scott Stephenson starts by asking himself a simple question: How do I want to be treated?"It's Golden Rule thinking," said Stephenson, president and chief operating officer of Verisk Analytics (VRSK), a Jersey City, N.J.-based firm that offers risk assessment services.
